TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit SoapServerMessage extends System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessage

Docs.summary: Represents the data in a SOAP request received or a SOAP response sent by an XML Web service method at a specific . This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format: ## Examples The following code fragment is part of a SOAP extension that logs the SOAP messages sent and received by an XML Web service method. This specific fragment processes the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage> passed into the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapExtension.ProcessMessage%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method of the SOAP extension by writing properties of the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage> to the log file.

Docs.summary: Gets the SOAPAction HTTP request header field for the SOAP request or SOAP response.
Docs.value: The SOAPAction HTTP request header field for the SOAP request or SOAP response.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.Action%2A> property can be accessed during any <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage>.
## Examples The following code fragment is part of a SOAP extension that logs the SOAP messages sent and received by an XML Web service. This particular fragment outputs to that log file the value of the `SOAPAction` HTTP request header field.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void EnsureInStage() cil managed
.method familyhidebysig virtual instance void EnsureOutStage() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets a representation of the method prototype for the XML Web service method for which the SOAP request is intended.
Docs.value: A representing the XML Web service method for which the SOAP request is intended.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Although the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.MethodInfo%2A> property can be accessed during any stage, the method information is only available during <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage.AfterDeserialize> and <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage.BeforeSerialize>.
## Examples The following code fragment is part of a SOAP extension that logs the SOAP messages sent and received by an XML Web service. This particular fragment outputs to that log file the name of the XML Web service method requested.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the client waits for the server to finish processing an XML Web service method.
Docs.value: if the client waits for the server to completely process a method; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapDocumentMethodAttribute> or <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapRpcMethodAttribute> applied to an XML Web service method or XML Web service client can specify whether the XML Web service method is one way or not by setting the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapDocumentMethodAttribute.OneWay%2A> property of the attribute.
The <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.OneWay%2A> property can be accessed during any <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage>.
## Examples The following code fragment is part of a SOAP extension that logs the SOAP messages sent and received by an XML Web service. This particular fragment outputs to that log file a phrase stating the XML Web service method is one-way, when the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.OneWay%2A> property is `true`.

Docs.summary: Gets the instance of the class handling the method invocation on the Web server.
Docs.value: The instance of the class implementing the XML Web service.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.Server%2A> property is an instance of the class implementing the XML Web service. If a SOAP extension knew ahead of time the type of the class, it could cast <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.Server%2A> to that type and access properties and methods of the class implementing the XML Web service. The <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.Server%2A> property can be accessed during <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage.AfterDeserialize> or <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage.BeforeSerialize>.
## Examples The following code fragment is part of a SOAP extension that logs the SOAP messages sent and received by an XML Web service. This particular fragment outputs to the log file the type of the XML Web service, if it is `MathSvc`.

Docs.summary: Gets the version of the SOAP protocol used to communicate with the XML Web service.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.SoapVersion%2A> property is guaranteed to be valid after the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage.BeforeDeserialize> stage. In the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage.BeforeDeserialize> stage the property is available, but the SOAP message has not been completely processed and SOAP extensions that may alter the contents of the SOAP message have not run.

Docs.summary: Gets the base URL of the XML Web service.
Docs.value: The base URL of the XML Web service.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapServerMessage.Url%2A> property can be accessed during any <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapMessageStage>.
## Examples The following code fragment is part of a SOAP extension that logs the SOAP messages sent and received by an XML Web service. This particular fragment outputs to that log file the URL of the XML Web service.
